addressleaf.section: To the right honorable my very singular good Lord the L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

24 Ja
n
1592
M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
By M
r
Brune.

page.lettertext:
fol.27r
May it please yo
r
good L. The bearer heerof
M
r
Brune
, whose letter unto me from
Amsterdam
M
r
Brune
I sent in my last
e 16 of this moneth, upon
e sight
of my answear, is come hither to
e Hage, and is
very well contented, upon talke between us, to sur-
cease his suite in these contreis, and repaire in person
to yo
r
L. w
t
out attending any passeport. For I
have fully persuaded him,
at
e cariage of my letter
to yo
r
L. and indorsed upon, For her
Hig
es
spe-
cial service, will be warrant good enough to protect
him from his credito
rs
: and though it were not
sufficient, yet
e occasion of his comming being knowen
to yo
r
L. he might be well assured,
at p
nt
order
will be taken for his safe being there, w
t
further con-
sideration for his charges, and travail. And
forasmuche as those maters, w
ch
he will signifie unto
yo
w
, concerne some great abuses,
at are practised
heere, he thought it very requisit, to discover them
unto me: and I attend to knowe upon it, howe yo
r
L. will be pleased to commaund me to proceede.
What disorders are committed in
e Mintes
Mint.
of these contreis, aswell in regard of
e multitude of
them, as of other badde courses, M
r
Brune can
informe yo
w
, as muche as
is
needefull. The state
of
e contrey doth grieve at it greatly, and finde
very hardly any meanes, as this gouvernment
standes, to redresse it by autoritie. Nevertheles
at
eir last assemblie in No
v
they resolved w
t
this
Councel,
to establishe those orders,
at were pub-
lished by Placart, in
e yere 86 w
t
consent of my
L. of Leicester
. M
r
Brune hath w
t
him a copie of
e Placart, and I have sent an Extract heereinclosed
fol.27v
of their last resolution. Having lately
bin enjoined, by a letter from her Ma
tie
to resume
the cause of
Coronel Sonoy
, I have delivered her letter
in their ordinary college, and as her Hig
es
required
I have touched them roundly, for
e sleight regard
at
they have had to her instant intercession, w
ch
I also
exhibited in writing unto them, and have sent yo
w
the transcript. I have also commoned in suche
sort w
t
some in particular,
at nowe I am in hope,
more then ever heere tofore. Howbeit because it is
a mater
at can not be resolved, but in a meeting
of
e Deputies of all
e townes of
Holland,
w
ch
assem-
ble not heere till
e 28 of
e next, they have differred
till then to determine upon it. In
e meane
while, it will steede
e Coronel very muche, if her
Ma
tie
will continue to speake to
M
r
Caron
, in confor-
mitie of
at, w
ch
I have proposed. Wherof I knowe
from time to time he will advertise those of Hol-
land, w
ch
will quicken them muche against the
time. The
General states
, who ap-
pointed to meete about
e middle of this moneth, are
not like to come together, till
e end of
e next.
For some of
e Provinces, as it seemeth, will not
yeld to contribut, as it hath bin required, to the
next sommers service: whereby it is supposed, it
will be late er they beginne, and happely for this
sommer they will doe very litle. It is
e opini
o
of some,
at they will onely attempt
e blocking of
Gertrudenbergh
, and make excursions into
Bra-
bant
, w
t
out exploiting any thing els: albeit it is
said,
at
e
states of Friseland
will endevo
r
in like
maner
e blocking of
Groeninghen.
fol.28r
The
Count Solmes
is come hither out of
Zeland,
to
require some helpe of those of Holland, for making a
certaine roade, about
e quarters of
Hulst,
wherto
they will graunt him a 1000 souldiers.
Wheras I have written heeretofore,
at
M
r
Buzenval
had moved
e states in
e
kinges
behalf, to aide him
this sommer w
t
2000 men for 3 or 4 monethes, all
the contributing Provinces,
Utrecht
excepted, have
passed their consents, to pay to
at purpose 2500
li
ste
r
every moneth, for 4 monethes together, and to leave
unto
e King, to levie
e men. But this
is
onely so
concluded in
e Provinces a part, w
ch
must be con-
firmed at
eir general meeting, where we hope
at
those of Utrecht will assent w
t
e rest: albeit it is
thought, if they should not,
at
e rest of
e Provinces
will supplie their defect. They are
greatly heere inquisitive, to knowe in w
at
maner
they shall be holpen by her Ma
tie
in respect of
e
Contract. W
ch
I signifie is a mater unknowen
unto me. But yet I speake, as of my self,
at con-
sidering
e importance of
e actions of
France,
and
at all
at they doe heere, is to very litle purpose, if
e King be overthrowen, I thinke her Hig
es
will de-
termine, to imploye all her meanes, aswell of her
auxiliary forces in these contreis, as of others from
home, to assist
e F
r
King: and will endevor
to induce
e people of this contrey, to convert their
charges also
at way, and to maintene heere at
home but a defensive warre. There is a mea-
ning therup
o
, as is told me by some, if her Hig
es
give over to assist them any longer, to dissolve
out of hand
e Councel of Estate.
fol.28v
They beginne to renue an old complaint, astouching
the service mony of
e Cautionarie townes, by reason
they are surcharged w
t
some bandes above
e Treatie.
And in
e Garrison of
Flushing
they will not allowe
e
companies of
S
r
Mathew Morgan
and
S
r
Coniers Clifford
to be of 200, till they see their Commission for it.
Being written unto about it from
S
r
Edmund Udal
, I
have wished him in any wise, to give good speeches to
e Burgmasters, and to intreat them to continue
their accustomed course in lodging all
e souldiers,
till her Ma
tie
shall be pleased to sette some other
order: and if then therup
o
they will not doe as
heeretofore, to shewe them in good termes,
at he should
be forced therein to use some autoritie, for
e avoi-
ding of disorder,
at might growe by suche souldiers,
as having no lodging would goe loosely straggling
in
e night. The
states of Holland
have newly conferred upon
e
sonne
of
e
Princesse
of Orenge
Henry Fredericke of Nassau, a regiment
of 20 c
o
panies, and have allowed him a pay of
80
li
ste
r
by
e moneth. But conditionally that it
shall be to maintene him for a while at
e schoole.
It is also secretly reported,
at there is a
matche concluded, w
ch
shall be shortly solemnised
between
e
Count Palatin
of
e Rhine, and
e eldest
daughter
of
e
Prince of Orenge
, by his
wife
of the
house of Bourbon, who is heere w
t
e Princesse, of
18 yeres of age. It is thought
at this Ester
e Princesse her self with all her traine, and
e rest
of
e sisters will bring her to
e Palsgrave.
Of
e Enemies actions heere is very litle notice,
as we have never had it better. It is said not-
w
t
standing,
at
e
old Count Mansfeld
, with the
fol.29r
Councel of Estate doth direct all affaires: and
that
Count Charles
his sonne doth commaunde the
troupes
at goe for France: w
ch
are thought to be 600
6000
foote, and 1500 horse. But as yet we can not heare,
that they are passed
e frontiers.
And thus
I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Ja
n
24 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden Tho. Bodley
